metadata.title: Xrn1 activity broadly represses RNA polymerase II occupancy at mammalian but not viral 1 promoters during herpesvirus infection 2 3

abstract.text: In mammalian cells, widespread acceleration of cytoplasmic mRNA degradation is linked to 17 impaired RNA polymerase II (Pol II) transcription. This mRNA decay-induced transcriptional 18 repression occurs during infection with gammaherpesviruses including Kaposi's sarcoma-19 associated herpesvirus (KSHV) and murine gammaherpesvirus 68 (MHV68), which encode an 20 mRNA endonuclease that initiates widespread RNA decay. Here, we show that MHV68-induced 21 mRNA decay leads to a genome-wide reduction of Pol II occupancy at mammalian promoters, 22 which requires the cellular 5'-3' exonuclease Xrn1. Viral genes, despite the fact that they require 23

Pol II for transcription, escape this transcriptional repression. Protection is not governed by viral 24 promoter sequences; instead, location on the viral genome is both necessary and sufficient to 25 escape the transcriptional repression effects of mRNA decay. We hypothesize that the ability to 26 escape from transcriptional repression is linked to the conformation of viral DNA in replication 27 compartments, providing a means for these viruses to counteract decay-induced viral transcript 28 loss. 29 30

body_text.text: Regulating messenger RNA (mRNA) abundance is of central importance during both 32 cellular homeostasis and disease. While it is intuitive that transcriptional changes in the nucleus 33 impact RNA levels in the cytoplasm, evidence in both yeast and mammalian cells now indicates 34 that the converse is also true: altered cytoplasmic mRNA decay rates can broadly impact 35 transcription by RNA polymerase II (Pol II). In yeast, stabilizing the cytoplasmic mRNA pool by 36 removing mRNA decay factors such as Xrn1 mRNA specific endoribonucleases and/or activating host nucleases. The 109 variability between replicates in R443I recovery is likely due to differences in the extent of host 110 shutoff reduction between replicates (Supp Figure 1C) . 111
To assess the stage of transcription impacted by RNA decay, we compared the amount of 112

Pol II in promoter regions (-50 to +200) and the amount of Pol II in gene bodies (+200 to +5000) 113 between mock and infected samples. Consistent with the above analyses, MHV68 infected cells 114 contained markedly less promoter proximal Pol II than uninfected cells, and this signal was 115 partially recovered in the R443I infection ( Fig 1D) . Genes with impaired Pol II promoter binding 116 during MHV68 infection also had less Pol II within the gene body compared to mock infected 117 cells, which again was not observed during R443I infection ( Fig 1D) . Notably, the difference in 118 regression line slopes between MHV68 and mock infected cells was clearly more marked when 119 comparing Pol II promoter occupancy than gene body occupancy, suggesting that the primary 120 transcriptional defect is at the stage of initiation. This is consistent with data from previous 121 studies that found no defect in serine 2 phosphorylation of elongating Pol II and no consistent 122 change to Pol II elongation during MHV68 infection ; Gilbertson et al. 123 2018.). 124

Finally, to assess if RNA decay affected transcription termination, we binned sequencing 125 reads between 1kb upstream and 1kb downstream of the transcription termination site (TTS) (Fig  126   1E, Supp Fig 1D) . TTS-proximal Pol II shows no defect in termination in either infection 127 condition, suggesting Pol II removal from host transcripts is not impacted by MHV68 infection 128 or by RNA decay. 129 130 Pol II Loss is dependent on Xrn1 131 Our previous work implicated the catalytic activity of the host 5'-3' exoribonuclease 132 Xrn1 as necessary for the RNA-decay dependent loss of Pol II at several individual host genes 133 . To determine the extent to which mRNA decay-induced Pol II 134 repression is dependent on Xrn1, we measured Pol II occupancy by ChIPseq in mock and 135 MHV68 infected cells upon depletion of Xrn1 using siRNA (Fig 2A) . Remarkably, knockdown 136 of Xrn1 resulted in a near complete recovery of Pol II promoter occupancy in MC57G cells 137 infected with WT MHV68 (Fig 2B, Supp Fig 2A) . We validated these findings using 138 independent biological replicates at Rplp0 and Fus by ChIP qPCR (Fig 2C) . On a gene-by-gene 139 basis, we observed similar levels of Pol II at promoters in mock and infected cells depleted of 140 Xrn1 ( Fig 2D, Supp Fig 2B) . Fig 2E shows with a slightly higher signal in the R443I infection ( Fig 3A) . Indeed, there was a robust and 154 widespread Pol II signal in both infection conditions across the viral genome ( Fig 3B) . Thus, 155 herpesviral genes appear to escape mRNA decay-induced transcriptional repression. 156

In contrast to host genes, we did not observe peaks of promoter-proximal Pol II on the 157 viral genome in our ChIPseq data (see Fig 3A, B) . Pol II ChIP qPCR across various regions of 158 ORF54 and ORF37 also showed a similar Pol II signal throughout each gene body and at their 159 promoter. We did note a decrease in signal near the TTS of ORF54, however this was true for 160 both WT and R443I infections ( Fig 3C) We then tested whether viral promoter sequence elements were sufficient to enable 190 escape by querying whether they remained immune to transcriptional repression upon relocation 191 from the viral genome into the host DNA. We inserted the MHV68 late promoter M7 or the 192 KSHV LANA promoter upstream of a puromycin resistance cassette into 293T cell chromatin 193 using either lentiviral transduction or random plasmid DNA integration, respectively. We 194 induced mRNA decay and host transcriptional repression in these cells by expression of MHV68 195 muSOX or the herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) endonuclease vhs. Similar to the host 196 promoters Gapdh and Rplp0, Pol II recruitment to both integrated viral promoters was repressed 197 upon induction of mRNA decay (Fig 5A, 5B) . 198

To confirm that viral promoters integrated into the host genome were also repressed in 199 the context of infection, we infected MC57G cells containing an integrated MHV68 M4 200 promoter-driven puromycin cassette with MHV68. Indeed, the M4 promoter was repressed to a 201 similar degree as host Fus and Rplp0 promoters during infection with WT MHV68 but not the 202 mRNA decay-deficient MHV68 R443I (Fig 5C) . In summary, these data argue against the 203 presence of protective elements within viral promoters, and instead suggest that the chromatin 204 context or location on the viral genome underlies escape from mRNA decay-induced 205 transcriptional repression. 206 207 Non-MHV68 promoters escape repression on the viral genome 208 A prediction from the above results is that non-MHV68 promoters would gain protection 209 from transcriptional repression when present on the replicating viral genome. To test this, we 210 measured the Pol II occupancy and transcriptional potential of the cytomegalovirus (CMV) 211 promoter, which drives green fluorescent protein (GFP) expression on the MHV68 genome. 212

Unlike alpha-and gammaherpesviruses, the betaherpesvirus CMV does not accelerate mRNA 213 decay. Furthermore, in either a plasmid context or when integrated into 293T cells, the CMV 214 promoter is strongly repressed during muSOX-induced mRNA decay (Fig 6A, B) . However, 215 placed in the context of the replicating MHV68 genome, the CMV-GFP promoter had a Pol II 216
ChIPseq signal during both MHV68 WT and R443I infection that was not markedly different 217 from several other representative viral genes (ORFs 4, 25, 48, 52, 72, M11) ( Fig 6C) . 218

Finally, we evaluated whether lytically replicating viral DNA was necessary to confer 219 escape from transcriptional repression, or whether some other feature of the non-replicating viral 220 genome was important. To this end, we examined Pol II occupancy at promoters of several genes 221 expressed from the KSHV genome during latent infection in 293T cells, when the viral DNA is 222 maintained as an episome but not amplified in replication compartments. Latent infection does 223 not promote mRNA turnover, and thus we transfected muSOX into these cells to stimulate 224 mRNA turnover in the absence of lytic replication. Similar to the host genes Gapdh and Rplp0, 225

we observed an RNA decay-induced repression of Pol II occupancy at the latent viral promoter 226 LANA and the viral K1 promoter was repressed in 4 out of 5 experiments ( Fig 6D) . We also 227 observed repression of the human Ef1α promoter, which is present on the Bac16 KSHV viral 228 episome as a driver of the GFP reporter gene (Fig 6D) . In sum, these observations indicate that Here, we demonstrate that virus-induced mRNA decay broadly decreases Pol II 235 recruitment to mammalian promoters, extending prior observations made with individual cellular 236 genes to the genomic scale. Although the MHV68 endonuclease muSOX cleaves the majority of 237 cytoplasmic mRNA, we found that the cellular 5'-3' exonuclease Xrn1, which degrades these 238 cleaved fragments, is essential for inhibiting Pol II recruitment across the mammalian genome. 239
In contrast, promoters on the replicating viral genome recruit Pol II with similar efficiency 240 during normal or accelerated mRNA decay, indicating that they escape transcriptional inhibition.

FIGREF2.text: 241This protection is lost upon relocation of the viral promoters into the host genome or when the 242 viral genome is in a latent state, emphasizing the importance of DNA context and replication 243 state, rather than promoter sequence, in determining the transcriptional response to accelerated 244 mRNA decay. 245Across the host genome, Pol II occupancy appears to be most strongly affected at the 246 stage of recruitment. The reduction in promoter-proximal Pol II is propagated into the gene body, 247 although the differences there were less pronounced, suggesting that once transcription of a gene 248 initiates there are not subsequent blocks to elongation. This agrees with prior studies of 249 individual host loci in MHV68 infected or muSOX expressing cells; 250Gilbertson et al. 2018). We also did not observe a defect in transcription termination, or evidence 251 of polymerases on the DNA after TSSs, suggesting that the gammaherpesvirus MHV68 does not 252 induce the termination defect and run-on transcription of host genes recently described in HSV-1 253(Rutkowski et al. 2015). 254Two pieces of evidence indicate that reduction of Pol II at host genes is unlikely due to 255 sequestration of or competition for the transcription machinery by the viral DNA. First, infection 256 with the mRNA decay mutant virus R443I, which replicates its viral genome to WT levels 257(Richner et al. 2011), does not induce the widespread reduction in Pol II recruitment to host 258 promoters. Second, transfection of muSOX alone (or other broad acting viral endonucleases) in 259 the absence of viral infection is sufficient to induce transcriptional repression at host promoters. 260 Therefore, we instead favor the hypothesis that one or more cellular proteins released from 261 degrading mRNA fragments triggers a signaling event that restricts transcription machinery 262 occupancy of mammalian chromatin(Gilbertson et al. 2018). 263Reduced Pol II occupancy of the host genome during MHV68 infection parallels 264 infection data from the alphaherpesvirus HSV-1. HSV-1 infection results in a genome-wide 265 reduction in Pol II occupancy of host chromatin and reduced nascent RNA production of the 266 majority of host transcripts(Rutkowski et al. 2015;Abrisch et al. 2016;Spencer et al. 1997). 267 Furthermore, early data showed that while the endogenous mouse β-globin locus was 268 transcriptionally repressed during HSV-1 infection, its expression was rescued upon integration 269 of the β-globin gene into the HSV-1 genome(Smiley et al. 1987;Smibert & Smiley 1990). 270 Experiments with gene-specific null viruses have implicated immediate early (IE) proteins in the 271 HSV-1 transcriptional repression phenotype, including ICP27, which can accelerate mRNA 272 turnover (Spencer et al. 1997; Smiley 2004). Additionally, we have previously published, and 273 confirm in this report, that transfection of HSV-1 vhs, another broad acting endoribonuclease, is 274 sufficient to induce reduced Pol II occupancy of several host promoters (Abernathy et al. 275 2015).Thus, in addition to targeting host and viral mRNAs for cytoplasmic decay, both alpha and 276 gammaherpesviruses restrict Pol II occupancy of the host genome, although additional work is 277 needed to establish whether the underlying mechanism is similar. 278 During the lytic stage of herpesvirus infection, viral DNA is localized to replication 279 compartments. These non-membrane bound structures are sites of viral genome replication, 280 transcription, and packaging (Schmid et al. 2014).They are enriched for many host and viral 281 proteins involved in these processes, including chromatin modifying factors and Pol II 282 (Dembowski & DeLuca 2015; Rice et al. 1994; Li et al. 2018). Replication compartments grow 283 and coalesce over infection, excluding host chromatin, which becomes pushed to the nuclear 284 periphery (Chang et al. n.d.; Taylor et al. 2003; Monier et al. 2000). We recently showed that 285 muSOX and Xrn1-coordinated mRNA decay causes differential trafficking of many cellular 286 RNA binding proteins between the cytoplasm and nucleus (Gilbertson et al. 2018). Knockdown 287 and overexpression studies suggested that at least one of these proteins, PABPC, is associated 288 with transcriptional repression. Here, we detected PABPC in viral replication compartments of 289 infected cell nuclei, indicating that selective exclusion of PABPC from these compartments is290 not the mechanism by which the viral genome escapes repression. Instead, we hypothesize that 291 either the state of viral DNA or other protective features of the replication compartment confers 292 escape from transcriptional repression. 293 Protection from mRNA decay-induced transcriptional repression was not conferred to 294 host or viral promoters present on the latent viral episome, indicating that lytic phase viral DNA 295 replication or replication compartment formation is key to this phenotype. The latent genomes of 296 gammaherpesviruses including KSHV and Epstein Bar Virus (EBV) are heavily methylated and 297 histone-rich, with the exception of promoters of genes expressed during latency, the latent origin 298 of replication, and CTCF binding sites (Günther & Grundhoff 2010; Szyf et al. 1985; Hilton et 299 al. 2013). Notably, during latency key lytic promoters like RTA contain both the activating 300 H3K4me3 and the repressive H3K27me3 histone marks, representing a 'poised' state (Toth et al. 301 2010). Rapid changes shortly after lytic cycle induction result in hypomethylation and removal 302 of repressive marks at early gene promoters(Günther & Grundhoff 2010; Toth et al. 2010) .At 303 later stages of infection, KSHV, EBV and HSV-1 genomes have been shown to be largely 304 nucleosome free, consistent with histones not being packaged in virions (Dembowski & DeLuca 305 2015; Monier et al. 2000; Hollingworth et al. 2017). For gammaherpesviruses, this is the stage at 306 which mRNA degradation is most pronounced. We therefore hypothesize that the 'open' state of 307 viral DNA during lytic replication plays an important role in facilitating Pol II recruitment under 308 conditions of accelerated cytoplasmic mRNA decay. Future work is geared towards exploring 309 whether widespread mRNA decay alters cellular chromatin states and DNA accessibility and, if 310 so, how this influences transcription factor recruitment. 311In conclusion, decay-coupled transcriptional repression is a novel facet of viral 312 manipulation of the cellular gene expression landscape. We hypothesize that the ability to escape 313 from transcriptional repression is linked to the open conformation of viral DNA in replication 314 compartments, and that this helps these viruses counteract decay-induced viral transcript loss. 315While widespread mRNA decay has been shown to facilitate immune evasion, gene expression 316 control, and latency establishment, the robust viral transcription we document here presents a 317 parsimonious explanation for a novel way in which the virus benefits from accelerated decay. and VHS and SOX have been previously published. 323 pCDEF3-GFP was used as a control. 324Primers used for qPCR and for cloning are listed in SuppTable 2. We hypothesize that pervasive transcription of the viral 161 genome at 24 hpi, compounded by the presence of TSSs on both Watson and Crick strands, 162 likely contributes to this phenotype. 163 PABPC is not excluded from viral replication compartments 165 We next considered how the viral genome maintains high levels of Pol II occupancy 166 during accelerated mRNA decay. During replication, viral DNA is transcribed within viral 167 replication compartments (RCs) in the nucleus, which exclude host DNA and thus stain poorly 168 with DAPI (Chang et al. n.d.; Taylor et al. 2003; Monier et al. 2000). Although they are not 169 membrane bound, these compartments selectively enrich for factors required for viral replication 170 (such as the viral processivity factor ORF59) and gene expression (such as Pol II) (Li et al. 2018; 171 Dembowski & DeLuca 2015; Rice et al. 1994). Virus-induced mRNA decay causes increased 172 trafficking of cytoplasmic poly(A) binding protein (PABPC) from the cytoplasm to the nucleus, 173 which we have recently linked to transcriptional repression (Kumar et al. 2011; Gilbertson et al. 174 2018). To determine whether replication compartments selectively exclude nuclear PABPC as a 175 means of avoiding transcriptional repression, we monitored its localization in cells lytically 176 infected with MHV68 or KSHV. As expected, the majority of infected cells displayed increased 177nuclear PABPC compared to unreactivated or uninfected cells as measured by 178 immunofluorescence (IF). We further saw that PABPC was not excluded from replication 179 compartments(Fig. 4A, B, Supp Fig 3A). To determine PABPC localization relative to RCs, we 180 first identified cells with RCs by looking for regions of Pol II or ORF59 staining that excluded 181 DAPI. We then quantified nuclear PABPC pixel intensity, and counted cells as having an 182 overlapping RC/PABPC signal when the PABPC pixel intensity was at least 2x that of cells 183 without nuclear PABPC from the same image. Indeed, 85 percent of MHV68 infected cells 184 showed overlapping PABPC/Pol II signal and 90 percent of reactivated iSLKs showed an 185 overlapping PABPC/ORF59 signal(Fig 4C).
